item.title: Comment on Thursday assorted links by Hazel Meade
item.description:
Reply to Phil S.:

Halloween has just gotten weird. In the course of ~two decades, I've seen our neighborhood go from the old standard (a few pumpkins/jack-o-lanterns by the front door, and maybe a "Boo!" sign) to an almost competitive state of huge displays across the front yards.

Meanwhile, the number of actual kids trick-or-treating has plummeted. We had ~8 at our door this year, vs. maybe 35-40ish a couple decades back.

Cosplay in general, for adults. Halloween. Marvel. Star Wars. Or, more on the political/social knife's edge - transgenderism.

I'm pro making Halloween a bigger holiday, but one change I've notices is that nobody actually yells 'Trick or Treat!' anymore.

One year, a bunch of kids came to the door and I said "OK, what do you say?" and they said "Please"! I was like "What????Wrong! You're supposed to say trick or treat!" And thne I made them yell TRICK OR TREAT at the top of their lungs before I would give them any candy.

The kids these days ...

item.title: Comment on Prediction Markets for the Win by Marky Mark
item.description:
As usual, Tabarrok gets the story about half right. Prediction markets did NOT predict a Trump win across the board.

Polymarket, in particular, split between Harris winning the popular vote and Trump winning the election (or, more accurately, the electoral college).

The Iowa Electronic Market, the oldest PM, gave the election to the Democrats.

Other PMs were similarly equivocal.
